ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Time Point
Type of interview
Notes: 1 = In person; 2 = Phone; 3 = Mail; 4 = SIG-O only; 5 = Carp only

ElementDescription: Have you seen a counselor or therapist in the past TWO WEEKS?
Are they in the Multi-Systemic Therapy - Emerging Adult condition?
The therapist and I agreed on the overall goals for treatment.
The therapist and I agreed on the goals for sessions.
The therapist used some of my ideas when we decided how to solve my problems.
The therapist helped me set expectations and goals for myself.
The therapist made sure I agreed about how to include family, friends, or significant others in my treatment.
The therapist talked to me in a way I could understand.
I felt like my therapist was honest and straightforward with me.
The therapist made sure I knew which problems we were working on.
The therapist recommended that I do specific things to solve my problems.
The therapist's recommendations helped me work toward my goals almost every day.
The therapist asked about how well I followed recommendations from the previous session.
The therapist asked about the success (or lack of success) of recommendations from the previous session.
We talked about ways to avoid things that might cause me problems.
We talked about things that might make it hard for me to change.
The therapist checked to see whether tasks and assignments were completed from the last session.
The therapist made recommendations to help me change ways that I interact with people in my home (the people you currently live with).
The therapist made recommendations to help me change ways that I interact with people outside my home.
The therapist helped me talk with the people in my life to solve problems.
My therapist tried to understand what is good about the people in my life.
My therapist tried to understand what is good about me.
The therapist helped me believe I can change my behavior if I want to.
The therapist helped me identify my reasons for wanting to change.
The therapist helped me identify my reasons for not wanting to change.
I felt like my therapist tried to understand how my problems all fit together.
The therapist's recommendations helped me take more responsibility.
The therapist made sure we got a lot done during sessions.
My therapist and I talked about how I'm feeling (for example, unhappy, irritable, nervous, upset, out of control) or my mental health.
My therapist and I talked about how things are going at school or work (or my future plans for school or work).
My therapist and I talked about how my relationships with friends, family or significant others were going.
My therapist and I talked about my living situation (that is, where I live, how it's going).
My therapist and I talked about avoiding getting in trouble with the law.
Have you ever used alcohol or drugs?
My therapist and I talked about reducing or stopping my use of alcohol or drugs, or continuing to stay away from drugs.
Overall, how satisfied were you with your Therapist?
If you had the same need for help in the future, would you want to return to your Therapist?
If you had a friend with the same need for help, would you recommend your Therapist?

ElementDescription: Thinking about the conversation you had with your doctor about substance use during this visit, how much do you agree or disagree with each of the following statements? A. My doctor respected where I was with my alcohol or other drug use
Notes: 0= Strongly Disagree; 1= Disagree; 2= Neither Agree nor Disagree; 3= Agree; 4= Strongly Agree
